On Tuesday 10 May 2005 05:45, Arun J wrote:
> Folks,
> Sorry for absconding for some time..problem of being in a different
> timezone..
>
> Trying to elaborate my problem stmt as it lead to different interpretation:
> I have an API that needs to be tested. My tests are written for that
> API.  Now this is an API/SPI model.  Hence multiple implementation are
> made available for the SPI.  So what I wanted to do is to run the same
> set of tests on the same API but flipping the underlying SPI
> Implementation.  I wanted my test results to reflect this for
> different SPI implementation.

We have a similar situation for part of Jena. There is a Graph 
interface, and several Graph implementations (one [actually three, 
but two aren't part of the public interface) in memory, one in an RDB, 
one in BDB JE). Each one should satisfy the Graph tests. So, following
the model suggested elsewhere, we have an abstract base class with the 
tests in, with a method getGraph() which supplies the Graph to test, 
and subclasses of the abstract class which override getGraph() to
deliver an appropriate implementation. 

It works pretty well.

The subclasses can also have specialised tests. EG, a Graph is a set
of (S, P, O) triples. There's a generalised find(S, P, O) operation,
where S/P/O can be wildcards. Memory graphs have indexes which allow
queries to be directed to an index rather than doing a general search.
A specialised test for GraphMem ensures that the special-cased queries
don't use the default implementation of find(). 

-- 
Chris "electric hedgehog" Dollin
"The compiler is free to insert padding because it makes the struct 
look bigger and scares away predators." [Keith Thompson, comp.lang.c]
